utterances: Thank you.
Linda Stern.
She writes the personal finance column for Reuters.
Oh, yeah.
Can you give me some personal...
Yeah.
I'm just looking for some personal tips.
Yeah.
Stay with us.
Anticipating the big NASA announcement tomorrow, plus how the CIA became gay-friendly.
It's ALL THINGS CONSIDERED from NPR News.
From NPR News, this is ALL THINGS CONSIDERED.
I'm Robert Siegel.
And I'm Audie Cornish.
American businesses are hiring, but the pace is slowing down and that may be a sign of trouble for the economic recovery.
The U.S.
gained just 69,000 jobs in May.
We were seeing much better growth at the start of the year.
NPR's Chris Arnold reports on what's behind this change and what it means looking forward.
It's pretty amazing how many different kinds of businesses there are in this country.
If there's a need out there of any kind, some entrepreneur will start a company.
And, despite the worst recession in generations, there are still thousands of small businesses plugging away, trying to grow and hire more people.
This year, we hired two more technicians and we hope to hire one more.
Srinivas Konanki runs a business with his wife just outside Boston.
They employ 20 people and what they do is they calibrate just one type of scientific laboratory equipment.
They work on what are called pipettes, which measure and dispense liquids.
The company is called Pipette Calibration Services.
What I have in my hand is a single channel pipette.
It's a manual pipette.
As you notice, I can change the volume setting.
So this is basically like a fancy squirt gun.
I mean, you know, you just suck up a little water and squirt it out.
Right?
Squirt it.
The difference is, here, you actually measure what you're squirting, whereas, in a squirt gun, you're just shooting it.
And so this is very accurate volume.
Manjula Konanki says her husband knows a lot about pipettes.
Srinivas can talk to you for a few hours about that if you want to.
Yeah.
But a cup of coffee and an artful change of subject later and we get down to the matter at hand, job growth.
And, for any business, that has a lot to do with confidence.
If you're going to hire somebody, you have to be optimistic that business will keep picking up.
And we, as a small business, have been very careful as to how we spend our money.
And, lately, there's been plenty of cause to be concerned.
The economy in Europe is looking worse again.
Many European companies have research labs right around here, around Boston.
And when they make cuts, they make cuts all over and when that happens, we see our business cut down.
The other big concern for Srinivas is cutbacks in U.S.
government spending.
He's worried about whether the NIH will wind up getting cut.
That's the National Institutes of Health.
Even a couple of percentage points funding if they cut to the NIH, it definitely makes a big difference to all the labs out here.
And that'll definitely affect our business.
And these are the same things that many other companies and economists are thinking about, too.
The risks he talked about were risks of Europe.
Betsey Stevenson is a labor economist with the University of Pennsylvania's Wharton School.
She says Europe could be creating a headwind on hiring and she says many other businesses are worried about what the U.S.
government's going to do as we approach what's called the fiscal cliff at the end of the year.
Congress needs to decide if it's going to extend the Bush tax cuts, what to do with unemployment benefits and required spending cuts.
There's all sorts of things Congress needs to deal with.
Congress is saying we're going to make this difficult.
You know, this sends a signal to everyone in the economy that there's a potential for real damage to our economy coming in the future and you should prepare for it today.
Still, even with all these question marks, the U.S.
is managing to add some jobs every month.
We've had slow growth, but it is growth, not shrink.
That's David Kotok, the chief economist at Cumberland Advisors.
He says, yes, in recent months, we've been adding fewer jobs than we were at the start of the year and that's definitely disappointing, but Kotok actually sees some reasons to be optimistic.
I see three sectors now doing better.
The manufacturing sector is growing in the United States and, as it does, it produces a higher paying job.
Same thing, Kotok says, goes for the energy sector.
The rapid growth in natural gas exploration will mean a lot of work that pays well.
We're joined now by Donna Brazile.
Donna is a Democratic strategist and the author of Cooking With Grease: Stirring the Pots of American Politics.
We're also joined by Reverend Joseph Watkins.
He's part of the government relations group at Buchanan Ingersoll, and a former White House aid to former President George H.
W.
Bush.
Thank you both for joining us on Political Corner.
Thank you.
Thanks, Juan.
Let me start with an amazing piece that was written by Paul Weyrich, the chairman and CEO of the Free Congress Foundation and a well-known Republican, a conservative.
Here's the conclusion of a column that Mr. Weyrich wrote.
He writes: it remains to be seen if Republicans of the grassroots levels are ready for black Republicans to be elected.
I'm not sure they are.
This was a surprising column.
It goes through a number of the black candidates for major offices around the country in the upcoming 2006 elections.

Joe Watkins, I was surprised to see that here you have a stalwart Republican saying the Republican Party is not embracing these Republican candidates, despite all the talk from Ken Mehlmen, the Chairman of the GOP here in Washington.

This year for the first time in my memory, there are at least four and certainly more candidates, but four well known African Americans running for top political office in the country, and this is really something to behold.
Now, obviously, everybody is focused on the race against the Democrats in the fall, but before they had that race against the Democrats, they've got to win over people in their own party.
Now, Donna Brazile, let's look at the Democratic Party in the same way.
I think you have been through the fight in trying to get the Democratic Party to actually put the money, the organization, the structure; behind black candidates.

Even black people in terms of being a campaign manager like you were for Al Gore in 2000, it takes a lot of struggle just to get them to acknowledge, hey, wait a second, we need black people in leadership positions even though they typically get the lion's share of the black vote.
Let me just say, I fought this battle, and I continue to fight this battle.
2006 will be a historic year for one of the political parties.

If you look at the 36 gubernatorial races, the 33 senatorial races, African American voters will make the difference in terms of who control those state houses, as well as who controls the United States Senate.
In 1986, we had a terrific season where black voters turned out in such a remarkable numbers that the Democrats were able to regain the United States Senate.
That was the year that Ronald Reagan loss so many House seats as well as Senate seats.

Unless the Democratic Party invests resources in those communities early on, it's going to be very difficult to get out the type of vote that you need in a non-presidential year to ensure that the Democrats can make it past the finish line.

Well, Donna, what leverage do you have when you're talking to the leaders of the Democratic Party and saying, well, wait a second, you've got to put more money in to the black community if you are expecting to get out this vote.

The white leaders inside the Democratic Party must be convinced, and members of the Congressional Black Caucus already appealing to them now to assist them in educating and investing in these communities early on.
So it's important that the party understands and reach out and invest early in these communities and not ignore the black vote until three years before the election.
Are they listening to you?
I'm not the person that's making the appeal because I no longer serve in that capacity.
But I hope they listen to Jim Clyburn, Mel Watt and the members of the Congressional Black Caucus.
Topic number two, the president and his offensive, if you will, to stir up public support for the war in Iraq.
How well is the president doing with his press conference and his speeches this week in trying to stir support for the war effort?
I think the president is doing a really smart thing by going right to the people and telling them exactly what it is he stands for and why we're there.
And I think he did a great job in Cleveland a couple of days ago.
A lot of people have complained in the past that these events were staged; that the questions being thrown at the president were marshmallow questions; that the audiences were cherry picked.
But this clearly was not the case.
But the president had the chance to share with them why he's president of the United States and why he has the resolve that he does with regards to the war in Iraq.
The most important thing is to remember that history will be the judge of this presidency and of the importance of our involvement in Iraq.
